title: EXCHANGE --- Activision to Negotiate Agreement With Union
text:
"While first labor contracts can take some time to complete, we will meet CWA leaders at the bargaining table and work toward an agreement," he said.

He added that the company has made major investments in its quality-assurance team, which is responsible for testing games for bugs, in recent years, including increasing starting pay and converting temporary workers to full-time employees. The company has also expanded access to performance bonuses for the team, Mr. Kotick said.

The union will represent quality-assurance employees at Middleton, Wis.-based Raven Software, one of Activision's studios that helps make the popular "Call of Duty" franchise. A majority of the 27 employees in the group voted last month in favor of being represented by the CWA.

Tensions with the studio's employees flared last year when Activision ended contracts with about a dozen of its quality-assurance workers. More than 60 Raven workers walked out in protest and later some announced plans to unionize.

The unionization push also comes as workers at other U.S. companies, including Amazon.com Inc., Apple Inc. and Starbucks Corp., move to organize. Workers at grocery-store chain Trader Joe's filed this past week with a federal agency to hold a union election. Also this year, workers at Verizon Communications Inc. and Recreational Equipment Inc., or REI, unionized some locations.

The Covid-19 pandemic helped spotlight the role of essential workers who run warehouses and transport goods. More recently, labor shortages have given many workers the upper hand in negotiating with their employers, sparking a wave of union votes and strikes.

Activision, which is in the process of closing its deal to be bought by Microsoft Corp., has been under investigation by state and federal agencies over complaints by female employees of harassment, discrimination and retaliation.

---

Sarah E. Needleman contributed to this article.
